According to the National Institutes of Health, when a vessel is completely occluded (i.e., blocked), its resistance to blood flow is typically estimated as 100% (|100% - x|, where x is the percentage reduction in diameter). (1) 

In contrast, when a vessel has a partial occlusion, the measured resistance is generally lower than 100%, but still significantly higher than that of an open or patent vessel. This is because there are still some flow through the partially blocked segment, contributing to overall blood pressure and flow.
